name: Confucianism
description: Ancient Chinese philosophy emphasizing social harmony through proper relationships, filial piety, ritual propriety, and moral cultivation. Centers on the concept of ren (benevolence) and the importance of education and self-improvement.

relationships.description: Shares emphasis on character cultivation and moral excellence
Contrasts with legalist emphasis on strict laws over moral education
Both believe in universal moral principles accessible through reason

name: Taoism (Daoism)
description: Ancient Chinese philosophy emphasizing living in harmony with the Tao (the Way), naturalness, spontaneity, and wu wei (effortless action). Advocates simplicity and non-interference with natural order.

relationships.description: Rejects Confucian emphasis on social ritual and structured morality
Influenced anarchist thought through emphasis on minimal governance
Merged with Buddhism to form Chan/Zen Buddhism

name: Legalism
description: Ancient Chinese philosophy advocating strict laws, harsh punishments, and strong centralized authority. Believes human nature is selfish and requires external control rather than moral education.

relationships.description: Rejects moral education in favor of strict legal control
Provides early philosophical foundation for authoritarian governance
Shares cynical view of human nature and emphasis on power

name: Platonism
description: Ancient Greek philosophy centered on theory of Forms - abstract, perfect, eternal entities of which physical objects are imperfect copies. Emphasizes reason over senses and the immortality of the soul.

relationships.description: Established idealist metaphysics emphasizing mind/ideas over matter
Pioneered rationalist epistemology prioritizing reason over sensation
Influenced student Aristotle who both adopted and critiqued Platonic thought

name: Aristotelianism
description: Ancient Greek philosophy emphasizing empirical observation, logic, and the golden mean. Focuses on virtue as habit, teleological understanding of nature, and substance metaphysics.

relationships.description: Established virtue ethics focused on character and eudaimonia
Influenced empiricism through emphasis on observation
Became foundation of medieval Christian philosophy through Aquinas
Developed natural law theory based on human nature and teleology

name: Stoicism
description: Ancient Greco-Roman philosophy emphasizing virtue, reason, and acceptance of fate. Teaches control over emotions, living in accordance with nature, and distinguishing between what we can and cannot control.

relationships.description: Developed from Cynic philosophy while moderating its extreme asceticism
Shares focus on virtue as the highest good
Parallels Buddhist teachings on acceptance and emotional equanimity

name: Epicureanism
description: Ancient Greek philosophy focused on achieving happiness through pleasure, friendship, and absence of pain. Emphasizes simple living, atomistic materialism, and freedom from fear of death and gods.

relationships.description: Advocates pleasure as highest good but emphasizes intellectual over bodily pleasure
Developed atomistic materialism denying supernatural intervention
Influenced utilitarian focus on happiness and pleasure

name: Cynicism
description: Ancient Greek philosophy advocating living in virtue and agreement with nature, rejecting conventional desires for wealth, power, and fame. Promotes extreme asceticism and shameless honesty.

relationships.description: Influenced Stoicism which moderated its extreme practices
Exemplifies ascetic rejection of material comfort

name: Skepticism
description: Philosophical position questioning the possibility of certain knowledge. Ancient skeptics advocated suspension of judgment, while modern forms question specific knowledge claims or methods.

relationships.description: Hume's empiricism led to skepticism about causation and induction
Questions rationalist claims to certain knowledge through reason alone
Influenced postmodern skepticism toward grand narratives and objective truth

name: Buddhism
description: Ancient Indian philosophy and religion centered on the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path. Teaches that suffering arises from attachment and can be overcome through enlightenment and cessation of desire.

relationships.description: Shares emphasis on acceptance, emotional control, and inner peace
Merged with Taoism to form Chan/Zen Buddhism
Often misunderstood as nihilistic but teaches liberation not meaninglessness

name: Natural Law Theory
description: Theory that certain rights and moral values are inherent in nature and can be discovered through reason, independent of human-made laws. Grounds morality in human nature and purpose.

relationships.description: Developed from Aristotelian teleology and virtue ethics
Integrated into Christian theology by Aquinas
Influenced social contract theories through concept of natural rights
Opposes legal positivism which separates law from morality

name: Thomism
description: Medieval synthesis of Aristotelian philosophy with Christian theology by Thomas Aquinas. Emphasizes reason and faith as complementary paths to truth, natural law, and Five Ways to prove God's existence.

relationships.description: Synthesized Aristotelian philosophy with Christian doctrine
Developed comprehensive natural law moral theory
Exemplifies scholastic method of systematic theological reasoning

name: Renaissance Humanism
description: Intellectual movement emphasizing human dignity, classical learning, and secular concerns. Focused on rhetoric, history, poetry, and moral philosophy based on Greek and Roman texts.

relationships.description: Influenced Enlightenment emphasis on reason and human potential
Promoted individual achievement and human-centered worldview
Contributed to growing secularization of thought

name: Rationalism
description: Epistemological position that reason is the primary source of knowledge, emphasizing deductive logic, innate ideas, and a priori truths. Knowledge derived from rational principles rather than sensory experience.

relationships.description: Opposes empiricist claim that knowledge comes primarily from sense experience
Continues Platonic tradition of prioritizing reason over senses
Often aligned with idealist metaphysics emphasizing mind over matter
Contributed to Enlightenment confidence in human reason

name: Empiricism
description: Epistemological view that knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience rather than innate ideas or pure reason. Emphasizes observation, experimentation, and a posteriori knowledge.

relationships.description: Opposes rationalist claim to knowledge through reason alone
Provides philosophical foundation for scientific method
Influenced positivist emphasis on observable, verifiable facts
Influenced pragmatist focus on practical experience

name: Social Contract Theory
description: Political theory that legitimate authority derives from consent of the governed, who surrender some freedoms for protection and social order. Government exists to serve the people who create it.

relationships.description: Provides theoretical foundation for liberal democracy and individual rights
Built on natural law concept of inherent human rights
Provides philosophical justification for democratic governance
Rejected by anarchists who deny legitimacy of any state authority

name: Liberalism
description: Political philosophy emphasizing individual liberty, equal rights, constitutional government, and free markets. Values consent of the governed, rule of law, and limited state power.

relationships.description: Built on social contract theory of consensual government
Generally aligned with capitalist economic systems
Promotes democratic governance and political participation
Historically opposed to conservative emphasis on tradition and hierarchy
Opposes socialist critique of private property and markets

name: Conservatism
description: Political ideology emphasizing tradition, social stability, gradual change, and preservation of established institutions. Skeptical of radical reform and values organic social development.

relationships.description: Opposes liberal emphasis on individual rights over traditional institutions
Aligned with traditionalist preservation of cultural heritage
Skeptical of Enlightenment faith in reason and progress

name: Enlightenment
description: Intellectual and philosophical movement emphasizing reason, science, individual rights, and progress. Challenged traditional authority, promoted religious tolerance, and advocated for human autonomy.

relationships.description: Promoted rationalist confidence in human reason
Influenced liberal political philosophy
Opposed by Romantic emphasis on emotion and tradition
Promoted secular governance and religious tolerance

name: Utilitarianism
description: Ethical theory that the right action is the one that maximizes overall happiness or well-being. Founded on consequentialist reasoning and the principle of 'greatest good for greatest number.'

relationships.description: Exemplifies consequentialist ethics judging actions by outcomes
Influenced liberal reform movements and policy
Opposes deontological emphasis on duties over consequences
Evolved from Epicurean focus on pleasure and happiness

name: Kantian Ethics (Deontology)
description: Moral philosophy based on duty and universal principles. Right action follows categorical imperatives regardless of consequences. Emphasizes human dignity and autonomy.

relationships.description: Established modern deontological ethics
Opposes utilitarian focus on consequences over duty
Exemplifies Enlightenment emphasis on reason and autonomy
Influenced through concept of rational self-legislation

name: Romanticism
description: Cultural and philosophical movement emphasizing emotion, imagination, nature, and individual expression. Reacted against Enlightenment rationalism and industrial modernity.

relationships.description: Opposed Enlightenment emphasis on pure reason over emotion
Influenced nationalism through emphasis on cultural uniqueness
Influenced existentialism through focus on individual authenticity

name: Hegelianism
description: Dialectical philosophy viewing history as progressive development of absolute spirit through thesis-antithesis-synthesis. Emphasizes idealism, holism, and the rationality of the real.

relationships.description: Exemplifies absolute idealism where reality is manifestation of mind/spirit
Dialectical method adopted by Marx and inverted to materialism
Heavily influenced Marxist historical and dialectical analysis
Promoted historicist view of ideas developing through time

name: Socialism
description: Political and economic ideology advocating collective or state ownership of means of production, emphasizing equality, cooperation, and democratic control over economy.

relationships.description: Fundamentally opposes capitalist private ownership and profit motive
Marxism is revolutionary form grounded in specific analysis
Communism is radical form seeking classless, stateless society
Moderate branch evolved into social democracy
Early utopian socialism preceded scientific socialism

name: Anarchism
description: Political philosophy opposing all forms of hierarchical authority and advocating for voluntary, cooperative organization without state power. Emphasizes individual freedom and mutual aid.

relationships.description: Shares socialist opposition to capitalism but rejects state socialism
Shares libertarian opposition to state power but from left perspective
Opposes Marxist dictatorship of proletariat and vanguard party
Rejects social contract justification for state authority
Some anarchists influenced by Taoist non-interference

name: Marxism
description: Revolutionary political and economic theory analyzing capitalism through class struggle and material conditions. Advocates for communism, worker control of production, and abolition of private property.

relationships.description: Founded on materialist inversion of Hegelian dialectics
Adopted and inverted Hegel's dialectical method
Represents scientific/revolutionary form of socialism
Provides theoretical foundation for communist movement
Fundamentally critiques and seeks to overthrow capitalism
Conflicts with anarchism over role of state in revolution

name: Communism
description: Revolutionary ideology seeking classless, stateless society with common ownership of means of production. Based on Marxist analysis of capitalism and historical materialism.

relationships.description: Based on Marxist theory and analysis
Represents revolutionary endpoint of socialist development
Seeks complete abolition of capitalist relations
Critics accuse communist states of totalitarianism

name: Existentialism
description: Philosophy emphasizing individual existence, freedom, choice, and responsibility. Rejects essence preceding existence, focuses on authentic living in face of absurdity and alienation.

relationships.description: Related to phenomenology's focus on lived experience
Shares absurdist recognition of meaninglessness but emphasizes creating meaning
Responds to nihilism by asserting individual meaning-making
Influenced by Romantic emphasis on individual authenticity

name: Pragmatism
description: American philosophy evaluating ideas and beliefs by their practical consequences and usefulness. Truth is what works in practice; meaning derives from effects.

relationships.description: Evolved from empiricist emphasis on experience
Aligned with consequentialist focus on outcomes
Opposes rationalist search for absolute truths

name: Nationalism
description: Political ideology emphasizing nation as fundamental unit of political loyalty, promoting national sovereignty, cultural unity, and self-determination.

relationships.description: Influenced by Romantic emphasis on cultural uniqueness
Exploited by fascism for ultra-nationalist authoritarianism
Opposes internationalist cooperation across borders
Can oppose foreign imperialism while promoting own expansion

name: Feminism
description: Political and philosophical movement advocating for women's rights, gender equality, and challenging patriarchal structures, norms, and assumptions across society.

relationships.description: Liberal feminism built on liberal rights tradition
Socialist feminism synthesizes with Marxist class analysis
Third-wave feminism influenced by postmodern theory
Part of broader social justice movements

name: Phenomenology
description: Philosophical method studying structures of consciousness and experience from first-person perspective. Brackets or suspends assumptions about external reality to examine phenomena as they appear.

relationships.description: Influenced existentialist focus on lived experience
Related to idealist focus on consciousness
Influenced hermeneutic approaches to interpretation

name: Logical Positivism
description: Philosophy asserting meaningful statements must be empirically verifiable or analytically true. Rejects metaphysics as meaningless; promotes unity of science and formal logic.

relationships.description: Represents radical form of empiricism with verification principle
Promotes science as only valid form of knowledge
Rejects metaphysical claims as meaningless
Contributed to analytic philosophy tradition

name: Fascism
description: Authoritarian ultra-nationalist ideology emphasizing strong centralized state, militarism, suppression of opposition, and often racial or national supremacy. Rejects liberalism, Marxism, and democracy.

relationships.description: Represents extreme form of authoritarian governance
Exploits nationalism for ultra-nationalist purposes
Often exemplifies totalitarian control of society
Fundamentally opposes liberal democracy and individual rights
Violently opposes Marxism and communism

name: Libertarianism
description: Political philosophy maximizing individual liberty and minimizing state power. Emphasizes property rights, free markets, voluntary association, and non-aggression principle.

relationships.description: Represents radical form of classical liberalism
Strongly supports laissez-faire capitalism
Right-libertarianism shares anarchist opposition to state from different basis
Opposes socialist state control of economy

name: Postmodernism
description: Philosophical movement skeptical of grand narratives, objective truth, and universal values. Emphasizes plurality, deconstruction, power relations, and cultural relativism.

relationships.description: Reacts against modernist faith in progress and reason
Often promotes epistemic and moral relativism
Influenced critical theory and identity politics
Critiques Enlightenment universalism and rationality

name: Environmentalism
description: Political and ethical movement emphasizing protection of natural environment, sustainability, biodiversity conservation, and addressing ecological degradation and climate change.

relationships.description: Includes deep ecology emphasizing intrinsic value of nature
Eco-socialists critique capitalism's environmental destruction
Some extend utilitarian concern to animals and ecosystems
Environmental justice links to social justice

name: Virtue Ethics
description: Ethical framework focusing on character and virtues rather than rules or consequences. Asks 'what kind of person should I be?' and emphasizes cultivation of moral excellence.

relationships.description: Based on Aristotelian eudaimonistic ethics
Opposes utilitarian focus on consequences over character
Opposes deontological focus on rules over virtues
Similar to Confucian emphasis on moral cultivation

name: Idealism
description: Metaphysical position that reality is fundamentally mental, experiential, or consciousness-dependent. Denies that matter exists independently of mind or perception.

relationships.description: Founded by Plato's theory of Forms
Fundamentally opposes materialist metaphysics
Influenced phenomenological focus on consciousness
Hegel developed absolute idealism

name: Materialism
description: Metaphysical position that only matter and physical processes exist. Denies existence of immaterial substances like souls or abstract forms independent of matter.

relationships.description: Fundamentally opposes idealist metaphysics
Epicurean atomism exemplified ancient materialism
Evolved into Marxist dialectical materialism
Physicalism is modern scientific form

name: Dialectical Materialism
description: Marxist philosophical framework combining Hegelian dialectics with materialism. Views historical development through material conditions and class struggle in dialectical process.

relationships.description: Inverted Hegel's idealist dialectics to materialist basis
Developed materialism with dialectical method
Provides philosophical foundation for Marxist theory
Applied to history as historical materialism

name: Nihilism
description: Philosophical position that life lacks objective meaning, purpose, or intrinsic value. Often associated with rejection of moral principles and traditional values.

relationships.description: Existentialism responds by asserting individual meaning-making
Absurdism accepts absurdity but seeks authentic living
Influenced postmodern skepticism toward universal values

name: Absurdism
description: Philosophy recognizing inherent conflict between human search for meaning and universe's meaninglessness. Advocates living authentically despite absurdity rather than despair or false hope.

relationships.description: Related to existentialism but rejects creating subjective meaning
Responds to nihilism by embracing life despite meaninglessness
Similar to Stoic acceptance of what cannot be changed

name: Transhumanism
description: Philosophy advocating use of technology to enhance human physical, cognitive, and psychological capabilities, potentially transcending biological limitations through science and technology.

relationships.description: Related to posthumanist questioning of human nature boundaries
Often aligned with utilitarian goal of reducing suffering
Opposed by bioconservatives warning of dehumanization

name: Capitalism
description: Economic system based on private ownership of means of production, market exchange, wage labor, and capital accumulation driven by profit motive. Production for exchange rather than use.

relationships.description: Aligned with liberal political economy
Fundamentally opposed by socialist critique
Subject of Marxist analysis and critique
Championed by libertarian free market advocates

name: Democracy
description: Political system where power is vested in the people, either directly or through elected representatives. Emphasizes political equality, majority rule, and protection of minority rights.

relationships.description: Liberal democracy combines with constitutional rights
Justified by social contract theory
Rejected by fascism as weak and decadent
Republicanism emphasizes civic virtue in democracy

name: Social Democracy
description: Political ideology combining socialist values with democratic processes. Advocates mixed economy with both private enterprise and strong welfare state, labor rights, and regulation.

relationships.description: Represents moderate reformist form of socialism
Seeks to regulate rather than abolish capitalism
Diverged from revolutionary Marxism toward reform
Synthesizes liberal democracy with socialist economics

name: Neoliberalism
description: Political-economic ideology emphasizing free markets, deregulation, privatization, and reduced government intervention. Extends market logic to social spheres and promotes global trade.

relationships.description: Revival of classical liberal economics
Promotes deregulated free market capitalism
Strongly opposes socialist state intervention
Challenges social democratic welfare state

name: Deontology
description: Ethical theory that judges morality of actions based on adherence to rules, duties, or principles rather than consequences. Right action follows moral law regardless of outcomes.

relationships.description: Kant's categorical imperative exemplifies deontological ethics
Opposes consequentialist focus on outcomes over duties
Contrasts with virtue ethics focus on character

name: Consequentialism
description: Ethical theory that judges morality solely by consequences of actions. Right action produces best overall outcome, regardless of the means or agent's intentions.

relationships.description: Utilitarianism is most famous consequentialist theory
Opposes deontological focus on duties over outcomes
Aligned with pragmatist focus on practical results

name: Critical Theory
description: Frankfurt School philosophical approach critiquing society and culture through integrating social sciences. Analyzes power structures, ideology, and seeks human emancipation.

relationships.description: Developed from Marxist critique of capitalism and ideology
Influenced postmodern emphasis on power and discourse
Dialectic of Enlightenment critiqued instrumental reason

name: Effective Altruism
description: Contemporary movement applying evidence and reason to determine most effective ways to benefit others. Emphasizes quantitative analysis of charitable impact and impartial concern for all.

relationships.description: Applies utilitarian ethics to philanthropy and careers
Based on consequentialist focus on outcomes
Employs rational analysis and cost-benefit reasoning

name: Cosmopolitanism
description: Philosophy viewing all humans as belonging to single moral community. Emphasizes universal human dignity over local or national loyalties and advocates global justice.

relationships.description: Stoics promoted cosmopolitan ideal of universal human community
Opposes nationalist prioritization of compatriots
Similar to internationalist cooperation across borders

name: Communitarianism
description: Political philosophy emphasizing community values, social bonds, and common good over individual rights. Critiques liberal individualism and emphasizes embedded social nature of persons.

relationships.description: Critiques liberal emphasis on individual autonomy over community
Shares conservative concern for tradition and social bonds
Related to republican emphasis on civic virtue

name: Utopianism
description: Political and philosophical tradition envisioning ideal societies. Ranges from detailed blueprints for perfect communities to general aspirations for radical social transformation.

relationships.description: Utopian socialism preceded Marxist scientific socialism
Influenced anarchist visions of stateless cooperation
Criticized by political realists as impractical idealism

name: Political Realism
description: International relations theory emphasizing power, national interest, and self-help in anarchic international system. Skeptical of morality and ideology in politics.

relationships.description: Similar to ancient Chinese Legalist cynicism about human nature
Opposes idealist faith in international cooperation and law
Critiques utopian visions as ignoring power realities
